title.narrative: PARTICIPATORY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN ASIA

description.narrative: To extend Forest Service efforts to improve forest policies and practices internationally, address climate change, conserve and protect critical global forest environments and resources, and improve the lives of forest-dependent peoples by awarding grants to and entering into cooperative agreements with nonprofit organizations, multilateral organizations, and other individuals, organizations, institutions, and governments engaged in forest conservation and management.

title.narrative: 2011 International Conference on Veterinary Science in Bangkok

description.narrative: Activity1: The Thai Veterinary Medical Association, collaborating with OIE, FAO and IICA organized the 2011 International Conference on Veterinary Science in Bangkok from October 26-28, 2011. At the conference knowledge on animal disease control and food security was shared and discussed. Funds were used to support an APHIS booth at the conference to promote prevention and control of avian influenza in the region. Activity 2: From January 1820, 2012, the Thai National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) organized the Workshop on Laboratory Biorisk Management in Bangkok. This workshop is one of three collaboration projects between NIAH and APHIS Bangkok. The workshop was attended by 42 Thai participants including veterinarians and scientists from NIAH, seven Regional Veterinary Research and Development Centers, the OIE Regional Reference Laboratory for Foot and Mouth Disease in Southeast Asia in Pakchong, and the Bureau of Quality Control of Livestock Products. The instructors of the workshop were Orn-Anong Ratchtrachenchai and Wattanapong Wutta from the Department of Medical Sci

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

title.narrative: Thai National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) Workshop

description.narrative: Activity 1: From January 18 20, 2012, the Thai National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) organized the Workshop on Laboratory Bio risk Management in Bangkok. The workshop was attended by 42 Thai participants including veterinarians and scientists from NIAH, seven Regional Veterinary Research and Development Centers, the OIE Regional Reference Laboratory for Foot and Mouth Disease in South East Asia in Pakchong, and the Bureau of Quality Control of Livestock Products. Two technical experts from the Department of Medical Sciences, Ministry of Public Health conducted the workshop. Participants gained a practical understanding of how to implement bio risk management strategies to minimize risks of infections through safe and secure practices in laboratories; Activity 2: APHIS Bangkok facilitated the donation of 50 copies of the Illustrated guide to Poultry Necropsy and Diagnosis to the Thai National Laboratory and the Thai Regional Laboratories. Activity 3:APHIS Bangkok attended the 2nd Thailand National One Health Forum Strengthen the network and lets move forward

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: Biotechnology Asia Regional Workshop. A workshop was held in preparation for Rio+20 meeting for the Convention on Biological Diversity, Meeting of the Parties (MOP6) to the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety, Conference of the Parties (COP11) to the Convention on Biological Diversity, and the CSD20 Meeting of the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development. The general aim of the Asian Regional Workshop was to discuss the topics of these events, how these global events are interrelated and how their outcomes can be implemented at the national level in a practical way

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: The Phytosanitary Irradiation Forum was organized by Chapman University (California) and the International Irradiation Association, in cooperation with the Thailand Institute of Nuclear Technology (TINT) and the Joint FAO-IAEA Program of the International Atomic Energy Agency. The objective of this forum was to increase the understanding of irradiation as a phytosanitary treatment to enhance global trade and prevent invasive pests, as well as to enhance communication and collaboration. Hosted by Chapman University, California, for the last seven years, the annual Phytosanitary Irradiation Forum has fostered the rapid global growth of this application. APHIS funded participants from the following countries (one each): Morocco-Office National de Scurit Sanitaire des Produits Alimentaires (ONSSA), Egypt-Central Administration of Plant Quarantine (CAPQ), Jordan-Plant Protection and Phytosanitary Directorate (PPPD), Saudi Arabia- General Directorate for Plant Quarantine, and UAE-Agricultural Development Department (ADP) as well as one APHIS Agricultural Specialist.

title.narrative: African Swine Fever Workshop for First Responders

description.narrative: APHIS is supporting Purdue University in the development and delivery of a comprehensive training program for first responders and field investigators in Asia that will assist in the management and resolution of outbreaks of African swine fever (ASF) on premises that house swine. In addition to formulation of outbreak response plans, the progrma will cover ASF epidemiology, diagnostics, and biosecurity applications.

description.narrative: The Borlaug Fellowship Program promotes food security and economic growth by providing training and collaborative research opportunities to fellows from developing and middle-income countries.

person-name.narrative: Daniel Herche and Tyson Whitney; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Foreign Agricultural Service, Salaries and Expenses

description.narrative: The Food for Progress Program provides for the donation of U.S. agricultural commodities to developing countries and emerging democracies that are committed to introducing or expanding free enterprise in their agricultural economies. The program has two primary strategic objectives: (1) increase agricultural productivity and (2) expand trade of agricultural products.
